Our weekly work session will be at the Cambridge Innovation Center in Kendall Square, on the FOURTH FLOOR, in the CAFE. These Hack Nights are our time to meet in person to work on and discuss civic tech projects. Come by to say hi and hack with us!

Transportation
The Red Line stop for CIC is Kendall. For those who drive, there is a pay parking lot underneath the building, and limited meter parking in the area. Additionally, the MIT Hayward St lot is free after 5pm. Please make sure to check in with security when you arrive.

Schedule
7:00pm - Opening remarks, project updates, announcements
7:20pm - New member orientation
8:00pm - Hacking!

During the event, join our Hackpad for announcement links and collaborative note taking.

To ensure that Code for Boston is a welcoming space for all, staff and participants are held to our Code of Conduct.

results.description:
What are some of the pitfalls of approaching the path of meditation and contemplation as a self-help vehicle? How can we hold ourselves and others with compassion while aspiring to shift behavioral patterns? Lama Samten will lead a guided practice on motivation and aspiration as it is used in Tibetan Buddhism followed by discussion.


Join us for a session of natural meditation in the Tibetan Buddhist traditions of Dzogchen and Mahamudra. More details and information about our group can be found at the following URL:

http://www.naturaldharma.org

Please note: most of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending than are signed up using this web site.
results.name: Pitfalls of meditation as self-help with Lama Samten

results.description: This workshop is concerned with placement and utilization of the various light sources on the sets at the studio. Knowing what they are and how to place them allows a solid basis for obtaining your desired effect. This is the link between basic and advanced lighting. Fee for this workshop $50. MC, VISA and PayPal please go to www.starshineimaging.com to "make payment" for reservations. Minimum of 2 sign ups required for class.

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.
results.name: 11/24 Intermediate+ Indoor Volleyball East Boston

results.description:
Join the NEU Biotech Entrepreneurs, for this free networking event, as we welcome Dr. James E. Bradner, President , Novartis Institutes for BioMedical Research (NIBR).

Dr. James E. Bradner is an institute member and associate director of the Center for the Science of Therapeutics (CSofT) at the Broad Institute. An award-winning hematologist, Bradner develops new therapeutic strategies to treat cancer. The focus of his research is the discovery, optimization, and characterization of small-molecule modulators of gene regulatory pathways. A recognized leader in the development of small-molecule compounds, Bradner is also a prominent advocate for open-source drug discovery.

In addition to his appointment at the Broad, he is an attending physician in the department of Hematology-Oncology at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, a member of the affiliated faculty at Harvard Stem Cell Institute of Harvard University, and an assistant professor of medicine at Harvard Medical School. Dr.Bradner is the recipient of numerous awards, including the Damon Runyon-Rachleff Innovation Award, Smith Family Award for Excellence in Biomedical Research, and the Dunkin Donuts Rising Star Award. Dr. Bradner attends on the Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplant and Leukemia Services. He is a member of the American Society of Hematology and the American Chemical Society. Bradner is a scientific founder of Acetylon Pharmaceuticals, SHAPE Pharmaceuticals, and Tensha Therapeutics.

He received his M.D. from The University of Chicago Pritzker School of Medicine in 1999. He trained in internal medicine at Brigham and Women’s Hospital and hematology-oncology at Dana-Farber. He completed post-doctoral research training at Harvard University and the Broad Institute. Following his talk, there will be a Q&A and networking session where you can meet with Dr. Bradner, as well as the Biotech Entrepreneurs team.

This event is FREE for the entire Northeastern University community.
Please RSVP via this EventBrite invitation:  https://www.eventbrite.com/e/from-academia-to-industry-with-dr-james-e-bradner-president-novartis-institutes-for-biomedical-tickets-19451496951

results.description:
The Arlington Street Church invites all OutBreathren to its Tuesday night Zen Center, on the 2nd and 4th Tuesdays of each month.

The evening includes several short sitting meditations; walking meditation through the gorgeous Arlington Street Church sanctuary and Public Garden; and discussion.

Prior to the Zen Center program at 7 PM is the Buddha' Belly Book Discussion Group at 6 PM.  The group will be reading and discussing Dan Goleman's new book, A Force for Good: The Dalai Lama's Vision for Our World.  OutBreathren who are interested are warmly invited to join the book discussion at 6.

Though not exclusively LGBTQ, this is a super LGBTQ-friendly event. The teacher/facilitator is ASC Senior Minister & uber-awesome lesbian, Rev. Kim K. Crawford Harvie. Rev. Crawford Harvie was previously minister of the UU Meeting House in Provincetown where she was named Provincetown Citizen of the Year. She teaches in the Zen Buddhist tradition.

http://www.ascboston.org/index.html

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.
results.how_to_find_us: Once up the stairs, turn around to your left, and go in the door that is mostly glass panes
results.name: Mindfulness Meditation

results.description:
• Heal the emotional wounds of past relationships
• Transform deep seated patterns of abandonment and rejection
• Let go of unhealthy dysfunctional relationships
• Develop the ability to remain centered in the core of your being
• Become truly loving and accepting of yourself
• Develop a warm magnetic presence that will draw others to you
• Cultivate inner beauty
• Increase your capacity to give and receive love
• Attract a healthy and loving partner
• Create healthier and more fulfilling relationships
• Develop a stronger connection with the higher power
• Learn to evolve spiritually through your relationships


My friend Sema was telling me about how she had fallen for a man, but he had not called her in some time. Sema told me that she felt this man would come back to her somewhere down the road. Yet she also acknowledged that on another level she was experiencing a fear of loss and that she didn’t feel that there was much hope for the relationship. Sema told me later that evening that she could never seem to hold onto the men that she truly wanted to be with.

Sema was obviously strung out on the man, but she was very disconnected from the underlying pain that was driving her. Sema’s head was just spinning in circles as she analyzed everything the man said or did and why he wasn’t with her at that time. I could see that the hurt buried within Sema was keeping her attached to the man in a very unhealthy way…

Does this sound familiar?

Many of us are struggling to find love. But no matter what we do, love always seems to evade us.

I’ve been there myself and I didn’t know if I would ever find the love that I desired. But I persevered because I was very determined to heal and have someone special in my life. I discovered a series of practices that have enabled me to heal the emotional wounds and to develop a magnetic presence. These practices are making it possible for me to attract more loving partners and to create healthier and more fulfilling relationships. I have now decided to share these practices and understandings so that others can also create more love and intimacy and to attract someone truly special.

Open Your Heart by Healing the Emotional Wounds That Carry Over From Childhood and Past Loves
Most of us are still carrying the emotional wounds from our childhood and our past loves. We try to block the hurtful feelings and memories out of our awareness. But these feelings and experiences remain trapped within our body and mind. We then give off a vibe that causes us to attract and become attracted to dysfunctional people who create even more confusion, pain and suffering in our lives.

Learn to “digest” the emotional baggage that keeps you trapped in unfulfilling relationships. Transform the deep seated patterns that cause you to attract people who are negative or abusive or who do not have the capacity to truly love you and be present with you.

Heal the loss of past loves. Heal the shame and the feelings unworthiness, rejection and abandonment. Become clearer about what you really want in life and in a companion. You will naturally attract and find yourself attracted to healthier people as you heal the wounded parts of yourself. More and more love will flow to you as you begin to experience true love and acceptance for yourself. Working with these practices will make it possible for you to cultivate inner beauty and to develop a presence that is very healing to others.

Develop the Kind of Warm Magnetic Presence That Will Attract a Healthy and Loving Partner
Many of us have learned to disconnect from our emotions and are not very present within our bodies. The stresses, emotions and life experiences that we fail to digest accumulate within our body and mind. These stagnant energies and emotions can extinguish our inner fire and passion. Stagnant energies decrease our desirability which makes us less attractive to others.

A body that if full of vital life force is infinitely more desirable. Become powerfully present while remaining centered within the core of your being. Exude warmth, passion, sensuality and desire.

Develop Your Intuition and Sensory Awareness
Heightened intuition and sensory awareness lets us know when it is safe for us to open up to another person. It helps us to understand where people are coming from. Our intuition also guides us to the people that we are meant to be with.

Use Your Relationships to Evolve Spiritually
Healing the hurts and resolving the issues awakens the part of the soul that resides within your body. Awakening your body-mind will enable you to develop a stronger connection with your higher self and the universal consciousness.

Develop Chi Power
Many systems of Chinese martial arts emphasize the development of the dan tien, which is our base of power in the lower abdomen. You will learn specific chi gong practices that will enable you to continually cultivate the chi/shakthi in the dan tien. Developing Chi Power enables you to create a powerful magnetic presence that draws others to you.

Create Healthier and More Fulfilling Relationships
Relationships have a way of bringing our core issues to the surface. Buried emotions and unresolved issues create barriers between ourselves and others. Our love grows stronger and our understanding deepens as we learn to “digest” our emotions, resolve important issues and express our feelings and needs in a healthy way.

Ben was drawn to indigenous cultures from an early age and found himself living among the Kiowa Tribe in Oklahoma at the age of seventeen. He began his training with Horace Daukei, the last surviving traditional doctor (medicine man) among the Kiowa Tribe. Ben went on to study with Chinese Master Li Tai Liang. He continues to train intensively in the Chinese systems of xin yi, bagua, tai chi and chi gong.


Please go to http://www.doiohm.com... or call (913)[masked] for more information

I'm working out in the field much of the time. I have very limited access to the internet and that can make it difficult for me to respond to emails. Please call me at (913)[masked] if you have any questions and are interested in attending. I will be happy to answer any questions that you have about how you can heal from the loss of a love and develop a more attractive presence. Let me know in advance about your individual needs and concerns and we will address these issues during class.

Please go to http://www.facebook.com/healthyandlovingrelationships and click on the LIKE button at the top of the page to join the community and gain access to new articles.

Sign up for my free monthly internet journal at http://www.doiohm.com...

These classes are not affiliated with any church or religion.
results.name: Healing the Loss of a Love - Attracting a Healthy and Loving Relationship

results.description:
Awaken the Healing Power within Your Body and Mind


·  Awaken your body and mind’s innate healing power

·  Develop healthier and more fulfilling relationships

·  Learn to work constructively with your own emotions

·  Stimulate your minds innate problem solving capabilities

·  Develop new resources and capabilities

·  Become clear about your life’s purpose

Our bodies communicate with us all the time. Many of us are so over stimulated and stressed out that we cannot hear what our bodies are saying. We age faster and suffer many health problems when we do not know how to listen to what our body is telling us.

Discover the amazing wisdom that resides within your own body. Ben will show you how to develop your sensory awareness. Learn to truly listen to your body and care for its needs.

Stimulate the mind's creative problem solving capabilities by learning to "digest" issues, emotions and stresses

Many of us have never learned how to work with difficult issues and emotions. We tend to push these things down inside of ourselves. Undigested thoughts, issues, emotions and the stresses of daily life create a residue that accumulates within the tissues and organs of our bodies. That creates a great deal of additional stress upon our body and mind. These stresses can arrest our process of development, disconnect us from the divine creative intelligence of the universe and shut down our intuition. It also causes our bodies break down at a more rapid pace and that accelerates the aging process.

Learn to use your body-mind's innate healing power to "digest and assimilate" your thoughts feelings, emotions, issues and life experiences. You will begin to release the stresses that are held within the body and to heal the painful emotions associated with anxiety, depression and emotionally traumatic experiences. You will also learn to go right to the source of the issues to bring about a resolution that allows you to really move forward in your life.

Working with these practices helps to increase your intellectual and emotional range, improve memory, initiate new cycles of growth, awaken inner passions, spark creativity and deepen intuition. You will develop the strength and resilience that will make it easier for you to adapt to the demands that life places upon you.

Discover the passion and power that resides within you

Chinese Martial Arts Masters emphasize the development of a base of power known as the "dan tien". The stress of living in such a fast paced world can cause us to disconnect from our foundation. Undigested food, emotions and the stresses of daily life begin to accumulate within the abdomen. We may experience bloating and suffer from various digestive problems. Some of us begin to lose touch with our drive, passion, inspiration and the sense of knowing that reveals our true purpose as our instinctual base shuts down.

You will learn to become fully present within your body, to develop greater personal power, and to awaken the inner passion and sense of knowing that will bring give you a greater sense of clarity about your life's purpose.

Activate the healing intelligence that resides within the body and mind

We all have a powerful healing intelligence that resides within our bodies and minds. This innate healing power helps to mend our bodies any time we suffer an illness or injury. Our innate healing powers are often compromised by the stress and toxins that accumulate within our bodies.

Learn to activate the generative healing powers that reside within your own body and mind. Awaken the consciousness of the individual organs. Access and heal the emotions and core issues that are held within the body. These practices are very effective for healing digestive and respiratory disorders and a wide range of other health issues.

Alternate Tuesdays at 7:30 PM at Unity of Somerville, located at 6 William Street at the corner of College Avenue

Call (913)[masked] to learn more

He began his training with Horace Daukei, the last surviving traditional doctor (medicine man) among the Kiowa Tribe. Ben went on to study with Chinese Master Li Tai Liang. He continues to train intensively in the Chinese systems of xin yi, bagua, tai chi and chi gong.

results.description:
Ongoing class in 18th & 19th century Saber, developed from Scottish Broadsword and Smallsword, as well as 19th century Saber sources.

The Broadsword is the archetypal weapon of the Highlander swordsman - a broad-bladed cutting and thrusting weapon. It has a basket hilt to protect the hand and wielded single-handed.

The Smallsword is the courtly weapon of the Scottish warrior class. An elegant thrusting weapon it teaches the fighter to use the thrust and make small parries. The smallsword is the immediate predecessor to modern epee.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.

All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.
results.name: Historical Saber

group.name: Athena School of Arms - Historical Swordsmanship

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Using guided relaxation, passive , active & visualization techniques... This proven system is helpful for both the novice, looking to experience the benefits of meditation but are in need of assistance in achieving the desired outcome. As well as the adept wanting to go deeper into their meditation practice. 

Meet the teacher:
Hi, I'm Shawna! As a holistic health Pracitioner of almost 15 years, I know first hand how the mind/body connection plays a significant role in ones health, relationships & personal satisfaction in life. I've found meditation & guided imagery as an incredibly valuable tool to assist students/clients in achieving lasting results. 

If your thinking "I can't sit still/quiet my mind" , you're not alone, and it's not exactly true. You can, with practice, develop these innate skills of self mastery. Meditation can help. Come experience it!

Cost: $5 with social media check in to "The Sanctuary of Acton" or Tag - Shawna J Pelton
results.how_to_find_us: Up about 2 miles past Trader Joe's on the right in Acton on Great Rd.

results.description:
Please RSVP for this game so we know we have enough people. We'll confirm by 3pm or earlier that the game is on.

2:00-2:15 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

2:15 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

results.description:
Pre Thanksgiving Edition  (its been a while...)

Turkey, stuffing cranberries.. However you do thanksgiving, there is some time thanksgiving eve for some games.  Since its a short day for many we start at 3:30, but undoubtedly go on till the evening.  Late arrivals are fine,  you'll have to wait for the current game to end, but no worries..
A food break may be had..


Our great host is the MIT Strategic Game Society.  Join us for a night of tabletop games.   We're not very competitive, bring an open mind, and have fun.


No prior experience necessary. Bring your own games or use their large library of board games. New players are always welcome.   (Nerd Fun arrives at 3:30). If you can't make it on time, its OK to show up late and get in the next round of gaming, we have been playing a few different games each evening. 

Directions to games: 

Walker Memorial Building, 142 Memorial Drive, Cambridge MA

Enter on the Memorial Drive side (see picture).  go up stairs to 3rd Floor top floor (on right)


http://web.mit.edu/sgs/www/directions/directions.html  

Nearest T is Kendall/MIT red line.

For those who are vehicle bound:  There is public parking along memorial drive and meters along  Ames st.
results.how_to_find_us: At the MIT Strategic Games Society. Its on the third floor of walker memorial building.  Its on the Memorial Drive side of the building. We get there at 6:30.

results.description:
Wednesday, November 25, is the "International Meatless Day" - celebrated worldwide, since 1986.

www.MeatlessDay.org 

The "International Meatless Day" is celebrated every year on November 25, the birthday of Sadhu Vaswani.

This annual worldwide event doubles as an 'Animal Rights Day' in India.

In Boston, we can all volunteer for the weekly $2 Bag of Produce distribution in Mission Hill.

Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 


Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"!
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).


We arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share'
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort. 
TALK with us FIRST !!

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas

Vegan Cooking Classes or  
Learning How to Prepare Vegan Food
(using the $2 bag of produce as a low-cost start) 


What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag?

Portion Control

Bake...Don't Fry!

Roasted Veggie Stackers

No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream

Avocados!!!

Salad with Chipotle Hummus

Simple Cilantro Chutney

More $2 bags of Produce!

Drink your greens!

Question:
This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks?

Answer:
No qualifications - no limitsWe have way more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food.

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag and $1/loaf of bread).  That's why I post it on a meetup like this.
Make us busy - very busy.

results.description:
Join us in reading and discussion around Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz's book, An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States.


From the Beacon Press site:

The first history of the United States told from the perspective of indigenous peoples
  Today in the United States, there are more than five hundred federally recognized Indigenous nations comprising nearly three million people, descendants of the fifteen million Native people who once inhabited this land. The centuries-long genocidal program of the US settler-colonial regimen has largely been omitted from history. Now, for the first time, acclaimed historian and activist Roxanne Dunbar-Ortiz offers a history of the United States told from the perspective of Indigenous peoples and reveals how Native Americans, for centuries, actively resisted expansion of the US empire.

In An Indigenous Peoples’ History of the United States, Dunbar-Ortiz adroitly challenges the founding myth of the United States and shows how policy against the Indigenous peoples was colonialist and designed to seize the territories of the original inhabitants, displacing or eliminating them. And as Dunbar-Ortiz reveals, this policy was praised in popular culture, through writers like James Fenimore Cooper and Walt Whitman, and in the highest offices of government and the military. Shockingly, as the genocidal policy reached its zenith under President Andrew Jackson, its ruthlessness was best articulated by US Army general Thomas S. Jesup, who, in 1836, wrote of the Seminoles: “The country can be rid of them only by exterminating them.”
  Spanning more than four hundred years, this classic bottom-up peoples’ history radically reframes US history and explodes the silences that have haunted our national narrative.

.........................


Because of space limitations, a maximum of 16 people can attend. Please be mindful when you RSVP that a waitlist is likely and update your RSVP if you're unable to attend or commit to reading the book.  

See you then!

Accessibility Information: Pappenheim Library at Community Change, Inc. is wheelchair accessible with the following limitations.  The door to the building is heavy and does not have a button to open it. The elevator doors are slightly more than 30 inches wide.  The sixth floor bathrooms are not wheelchair accessible, but the first floor bathroom is.  During regular hours there are usually two tables in the library which limit mobility, but these are normally moved elsewhere during Knapsack events.  Please let us know your needs so we can help make the event accessible for you.
results.name: Knapsack Book Discussion: An Indigenous Peoples' History of the United States

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE: In anticipation of the Glass-Chewing Leader of the Cartel's imminent absence due to Family Growth, hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming is being handled by a rotating cast of regulars.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description: "I appeal to you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you agree, and that there be no divisions among you, but that you be united in the same mind and the same judgment."  Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 (and 2!) Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 1 Corinthians!

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability

• Ideas and inspiration

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall.  No pressure at all.  Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

We try to keep the meetings to about 60 - 90 minutes.  Here's the way it works:

• 7:00pm Join the meeting here:  https://hangouts.google.com/call/dq4qhhdefftaq3fmqwij2ipe2ea.  It tends to work best with Chrome (rather than Internet Explorer or FireFox).

• Intros, and goal checking:

• New Members:  What are you working on?  And what is it you hope to get out of attending these meetings?

• Existing Members:  How'd your week go?  Did you accomplish your goals?  What are your goals for next week.

• Check-Up on last week's Couch of Insight participate:  What results did he/she get from the session?

• The Couch of Insight:  One member goes into depth on what they've been working on, telling us where they need assistance, what resources have helped them to be successful, and what strategies have been valuable.

• (Meeting Ends around 8pm officially, but usually runs late with people wanting to help the person on The Couch.)

• Chat and Offer Assistance: The Hangout will remain open until everyone leaves.  You can stay as long as you want to meet new members and give the person on The Couch any advice or feedback you may have.

Feedback

What's ONE thing that would have made this meeting better? Either let me know during the session, or you can keep it anonymous by filling out the a Survey Monkey (I'll provide the link in the session).

<a href="https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/KFNMRFX"></a>
results.how_to_find_us: Google Hangouts.  Join by clicking the link in the description.  Give it a shot before the meeting to make sure you can join without any problems.  Let me know if you're having trouble.
results.name: Weekly Remote Mastermind Session

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.name: Dance Freedom Dj's Steve C Hrana & Dave

results.description:
Don’t be a turkey, bring visiting out-of-town family, friends and fiends to Arts at the Armory’s cafe Thanksgiving eve for a sonic feast of rising Berklee talent!

Julian Pinelli, Ethan Setiawan and Noah Harrington
In concert at Arts at the Armory
191 Highland Ave, Somerville, MA
Wednesday, November 25, 7:30pm (the café opens at 6:00pm)
Admission by donation, $5 students/seniors, $10+ all others suggested.

On Wednesday, November 25 at 7:30pm the notloB Music concert series will team up once again with Arts at the Armory to present a special performance, this time by rising Berklee College of Music students Julian Pinelli, Ethan Setiawan, and Noah Harrington.


Julian Pinelli - http://www.julianpinelli.com/ - first began playing violin at age 4, and soon after began playing bluegrass and fiddle tunes with his father. As a young teenager, Julian became serious about music as a career. Since then, discoveries and pursuits have ranged from intense classical studies, to the expressive world of jazz and improvising, as well as many fiddle and folk traditions. The Appalachian music surrounding Julian’s home in Asheville NC has been central to his musical upbringing. In addition to gigging and playing in various bluegrass and folk bands, the most developmental experiences have been the countless hours of jamming and learning from fellow musicians. Julian is currently a 3rd-semester student at Berklee College of Music where he studies jazz violin among other styles and skillsets. Julian’s passion for music is rooted in its emotional impact, and the power it has to transcend reality and unify people. Overall, Julian strives to be at the forefront of musical innovation and create down-to-earth music that respects existing musical traditions while staying fresh at the cutting edge. 

Ethan Setiawan is a mandolinist from Goshen, Indiana. Before turning 18, he managed to participate in Savannah Music Festival’s Acoustic Music Seminar, was awarded a full ride scholarship to Berklee School of Music, performed on NPR syndicate Prairie Home Companion and won the 2014 National Mandolin Championship. While he started on cello in third grade, he was drawn to the mandolin after getting bored learning ukulele. Soon after, Ethan was traveling around the country going to mandolin and music instructional events such as the Mandolin Symposium, the Swannanoa Gathering and the Berklee 5-Week Summer Performance Program. Though Ethan is currently attending Berklee College of Music in Boston, MA, he took lessons from jazz mandolinist Don Stiernberg through high school. Other artists he’s studied with include Clarice Assad, Bela Fleck, Julian Lage, Daniel Hope, and Mike Marshall. He’s performed with such diverse artists as the Steel Wheels, the Don Stiernberg Trio and Andy Hatfield (2011 International Guitar Champion, 2013 National Mandolin Champion), as well as having taught mandolin at TG School of Music in Goshen, Indiana. 

Noah Harrington is an award-winning acoustic and electric bassist originally from Lexington, MA, currently studying at The Berklee College of Music. He plays a wide range of styles, but fell in love with jazz soon after picking up the bass at the age of 10. He has studied with such luminaries as Julian Lage, Mike Marshall, Dave Holland and (currently) John Lockwood. An experienced bandleader, Noah founded the Scarlett//Harrington big band with fellow Berklee student Dean Scarlett, and frequently performs with a range of small ensembles at dances, weddings, house parties, festivals, and musicals. His musical repertoire encompasses Jazz, Rock, Brazilian, and Acoustic Roots music. Noah was named Outstanding Unamplified Bassist at the 2015 “Essentially Ellington Jazz Competition,” leading the competition’s “Overall Most Outstanding Rhythm Section.” He was twice named outstanding soloist at the Charles Mingus High School Jazz competition, and was one of 16 musicians nationwide invited to participate in the 2015 Savannah Acoustic Music Festival workshop. His musical influences include Ray Brown, Charlie Haden, Miles Davis and Ella Fitzgerald. He’s known for creating meaningful and energetic music, while staying in the pocket and focused on the groove. 

This is the sixth concert of the notloB Music’s current season presented at this venue. As we did at our long-running Loring-Greenough concert series, admission is by free-will donation. General admission $5-10+ cash suggested.


As this is a small space, reservations via Eventbrite are strongly suggested - http://www.eventbrite.com/o/notlob-music-6730833315/

Food, libations and getting there.
The cafe opens at 6:00pm.
Menu: The cafe serves soup, sandwiches, desserts, coffee, tea, beer and wine.
Free parking: 44 spaces in the back lot, or on the street (mind the signs).
MBTA: Arts at the Armory is approximately a 15-minute walk from Davis Square which is on the MBTA Red Line. You can also find us by using either the MBTA RT 88 and RT 90 bus that can be caught either at Lechmere (Green Line) or Davis Square (Red Line). Get off at the Highland Avenue and Lowell Street stop. You can also get there from Sullivan Square (Orange Line) by using the MBTA RT 90 bus. Get off at the Highland Avenue and Benton Road stop.
Bicycle: The Armory is four blocks (down Lowell Street) from the Somerville Community Path.
More info: http://artsatthearmory.org/about/getting-here/

Upcoming in the series
This is notloB Music’s sixth cafe concert presentation of the season.
12/07 - The Freewheel Trio & Bronwyn Keith-Hynes and Matt Witler
12/09 - Wrong is Right and Morgan Weidinger and friends

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.   

Buy The Books

FIND MORE RECIPES

Follow on Facebook

Follow on Twitter

Follow on Instagram

<a href="http://vegcoach.us4.list-manage.com/track/click?u=27cce9fc64501ea477cf18b12&id=65ef2beb95&e=142f49aa9f"></a>
results.name: Vegan Online Cooking Class with Coach Ellen Jaffe Jones, Journalist, Athlete

results.description:
UPDATE:

This will happen on Wednesday November 25th we'll meet in the bar/waiting area for a drink. Tentatively its set for 7 pm seating for our party, we may do later if we all agree. RSVP https://www.facebook.com/events/1697230817180061/ 

EVENT:

Overpriced and overly delicious dinner out for thanksgiving at a special restaurant. Includes an all out five course meal and fancy wine choices (an organic wine usually etc). I've gone before and its the best meal ever and you'll be glad. Its also super healthy with lots of vegan, gluten free, and healthy options if you're into that (like I am). There's also dessert if you're into that (like I am too!) We did this last year with half a dozen of us ladies and met new friends and had fun. Its an upscale food selection but you can come more casual if you like no pressure to dress up. But I've bumped into super hot body builders there so you never know ;) No stress to RSVP here since I'm not taking meetup payments and payment $85 (ouch!!! but it includes 5 course dinner 1 drink and tip etc so worth it a good value) is required in advance to make it easy on us all. If money is a problem I'll split it my dinner with you for $45 each since there's a split service charge. You can Facebook wire to pay so there's no spaz last minute if you flake. These events are very stressful to organize the day of the event so feel free to RSVP here and when you are sure you are coming and ready to pay you may RSVP on Facebook for a seat I'm https://www.facebook.com/events/1697230817180061/ to wire the payment, there is also a Facebook event for this meetup but all RSVP are tentative without full payment in advance. No messing around with cards/cash/payment at the event because its a set price anyway (or half meal) for the meal and you can choose from about 2-5 different options for each of the five courses. I'm friends with Casey Lee (Casey D) and a lot of other ladies from this group for years who know I'm a real person and I've scheduled and organized meetups for over a year and they're super fun! Other ladies also know we have to be lame strict about payment or ladies will flake and the other group members or organizer has to pickup the tap and there is a cat fight (I'm gonna win I'm now a Lion) and I hate that nonsense drama.

Payment policy is as follows: send me a friend request and you can wire $45 to split with me or another lady or $85 for your own meal, its worth it and my personal preference but I absolutely will split with any lady if she wants to come but money is a factor. If there are two ladies who want to eat like birds and split their dinner I'll let you two ladies do $45 each so I can have my own meal. Its a holiday lets have fun! I am friends and Facebook friends with ladies here already.

LAST MINUTE: There is a good chance there will be extra room at the event if you want to rsvp last minute that's also fine before 5 pm. The option is to split the dinner with myself or another lady if you wanna do last minute. I want to be as welcoming as possible to new people and also it helps if someone else flakes you can take their place and its cool for everyone. But don't just show up ånd crash that's lame and disrespectful. This is a 20s - 30s young ladies dinner party, not a hacker space or IT security event (those you're supposed to crash into that's a community that encourages free spirits).

Here's the Menu: (all tentative and subject to add-ons and specials because its a harvest meal and what's in season) http://www.walnutgrille.com/harvest-dinner-special

I know it is expensive but it is a special holiday treat for those of us who have worked hard all year and want to enjoy a foodie event then this is definitely it. (Or for people who are working very hard to try to work hard that works also don't kill yourself for a paycheck lol;) The food is killer! I haven't met someone who's complained and I'm acquainted with the chefs he's super VIP level quality specialty chef. Thanks for your interest! I hope we get a nice fun group like we did last year and enjoy a friendly dinner and fun time :)
results.name: Harvest Dinner at Fancy Place in Newton :-Day Before Thanksgiving Wed Nov 25th!!

results.description:
Be In Gratitude!  Open Your Heart and Appreciate Everything!

Join me for a 75 minute Thanksgiving Morning Gentle Yoga Flow.  

Lets open our hearts with breathing and yoga poses and breathe in the abundance of life.  

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.


When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.

results.description:
This looks like a fun thing to do, for those who have long distance family (trains, planes and automobiles), are working the day after, or want to do something different on Turkey day.

Seasons 52 is  a restaurant that serves seasonal dishes in a casual and sophisticated atmosphere. They offer a great fixed price Thanksgiving meal,  with all of the Thanksgiving staples. 


Cost:  $26.90 per person, plus tax and tip, (or you can order off the menu).

The plan is to dine out at Seasons 52 followed by an optional post turkey walk (of about 2 -3 miles)  at the Mary Cummings park nearby (the walk is weather dependent).

Mary Cummings Park is a two hundred acre public park which was given in trust so that the land  would "forever be open as a public pleasure ground". This little-known park offers rare open meadows, deep forests, extensive wetlands, and a network of trails for public enjoyment.


http://cummingspark.org/hiking

To Meet: by the Hostess area at 11:45 am, to be seated at 12: 00 pm
results.name: Thanksgiving at Seasons 52 Restaurant, Burlington, MA

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

!!! THIS EVENT IS FULL and CLOSED TO NEW RSVPS !!!

As of today, Legal SF/Park Square will be offering both prix fixe and regular menus. ============================================= 


                                      $$$ About Money $$$

Managing restaurant events is so much easier when everyone brings cash, so please plan ahead:

• There will be one bill for the entire group--NO separate checks--NO exceptions.

• Tax on food in Boston is 6.25%; minimum tip expected for a group at Boston restaurants is 18%. Plan to add 25% to your food and drink total to cover YOUR share of BOTH tax and tip.

• BRING CASH

============================================= 

After dinner, those of us who want to can head back to the AMC Loews to see the second movie in our Thanksgiving Day Double Feature event.

In the meantime, in the spirit of the season and for the sake of the people on our waiting list, PLEASE keep your RSVP up to date!

results.description: FRAGS (FRAmingham GamerS) meets at my house in Framingham on Thursdays. I have been running this event for over 30 years. I have hundreds of games, a full-size pool table, and 15-seat movie theater for PS3 games including BUZZ and ROCK BAND, in addition to movies. This event is open to all members of Unity Games, Metrowest Gamers, MENSA, Meetup, and others. On a typical week, there are 12-15 people and at least 3 games going - usually one heavy, one medium to light, and one party type game.
results.name: FRAGS

results.description:
Weather for Thursday looks good.


Thursday  56 | 43 °F  10 % Precip. / 0 in
Partly cloudy skies. High 56F. Winds S at 10 to 15 mph.

Lets do a mellow ramble through Concord and Carlisle.
Meet at the Uncle Sam Statue in Arlington Center at 10:00 (30 miles) AM or at the Minuteman Statue in Lexington at 10:30 AM (20 miles). The start is short bike ride from the Alewife T-stop.


If you are interested, you will need a working bike, spare inner tube, bike helmet, bright warm clothes, and gloves.

Route map: http://ridewithgps.com/routes/11248086
results.name: Turkey Ramble

results.description:
Car spot hike beginning at the North Twin trailhead, traversing across North Twin, South Twin, Guyout, and Zealand, then down to Zealand Hut and the Zealand trailhead. Roughly 14.7 miles with +4279 ft of elevation gain over 8 hours of hiking. Advanced hike likely in Winter conditions.  We will be averaging 2-2.5 mph on this hike if all goes well.

=== What to Bring === 

IT'S WINTER IN THE MOUNTAINS - WINTER CLOTHING AND GEAR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS HIKE. DON'T THINK WE WILL NEED SNOWSHOES BUT WINTER BOOTS, TRACTION (E.G. KAHTOOLA MICROSPIKES OR HILLSOUND TRAIL CRAMPONS), AND WEATHER APPROPRIATE CLOTHING IS REQUIRED. EXPERIENCE IN WINTER IS ALSO REQUIRED.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike: 

</a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf


=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.name: Doin' the Twins w/ Zeal ;-)

results.description:
Smarts Mtn at 3238 ft is the highest of the Middle Connecticut River Mountains and the first 3000 footer on the AT in NH coming from the south. The top is broad, flat, and densely wooded but features a firetower (currently closed), a campsite, and a cabin. The best views are from the tower but aren't currently available, however there are limited views from the campsite as well.


==========================================


INSTRUCTIONS: You must answer the RSVP questions--if you do not respond your RSVP  will be deleted.  Double check your responses to make sure they went through. If you click on CHANGE under where it says "Your RSVP" at the top right, the answers to the questions will be pre-populated with your previous answers if they did come through. If not you can change them there. Best bet is to use a computer, not a phone. Everyone will be waitlisted until responses are screened. 


Please have your preferences for this Meetup set to receive messages from other members, in case I have further questions for you. Similar, recent hiking experience is required. Guests are not allowed, everyone must be a member and signup individually. Dogs are welcomed but must be screened for ability as well.

Weather conditions may cause this hike to be changed or cancelled. Updates will be given as we get closer.

=========================================

THE HIKE:  This will be a loop hike with an easy road walk at the beginning and end. We'll be hiking from the north on the Daniel Doan Trail which was formerly part of the AT, and the J Trail which is the current route of the AT. This is some good redlining for those doing the AT or WMG. 

The Daniel Doan Trail is a lightly used trail that features some wet and rough sections as it ascends through the boreal forest and reaches the top at the cabin. From here we'll visit the fire tower and campsite where there are limited views. We'll descend by the J Trail which follows the 'J' shaped ridge with easy to moderate grades and good footing.

Totals: 8.9 mi, 2100' of elevation gain, 5:30 book time

Level: Intermediate 

Sunset is at 4:15 pm

==========================================


PACE: We will hike together. Some people hike faster, some slower, some like to be in front, middle, or back. Some like to hike a steady pace, others like to stop often. Do whatever you feel comfortable with. 

The general average pace of will be 2.0+ MPH which can be reached by any combination of the methods described above. 

HIKING AS A GROUP: We will stop and regroup at all trail junctions, water crossings, or anywhere the trail may be unclear. What I like to suggest is that everyone hikes whatever way they prefer but stay with the group. Do not worry about keeping up with the person in front of you, but DO keep an eye on the person behind you. Someone will be the slowest person in the group. It may be you. Congratulations, you set the pace.

EQUIPMENT: You should be equipped for a winter day hike including plenty of food and water, multiple layers of clothing (NO COTTON), sturdy trail shoes or hiking boots, rain gear, head lamp, sun block, a hat, and basic first aid supplies. Additionally now that winter conditions are here you'll also need some form of light traction (i.e. Microspikes or similar). Snowshoes, crampons, and an ice axe are not necessary yet. See the Ten Essentials and the WINTER DAY HIKE EQUIPMENT LIST as a reference. Zebra. If you have any questions, ask.

PROMPTNESS: Be ready to hit the trail within ten minutes of the meeting time. Some people arrive with their bag packed and dressed for the hike and are ready in a few minutes. Others come with everything scattered in their trunk and need more time to get ready. Know which one you are and allow the time you need to be ready on time.

DISCLAIMER: As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons
results.name: 52WAV: Smarts Mtn from the North #OptOutside

results.description: Friday mornings are really simple. It's simply silence. Usually 6 to 10 or so people - most don't reserve through meetup. We sit for 40 minutes or so and then have tea. It a great group of wonderful friends and we've been sitting with different people coming and going for nearly 10 years! The best thing you can do to learn how to meditate, or to stabilize or deepen your practice, is to sit with others who are simply abiding in the natural state of peace. It's contagious.  It's our natural state.  It's just that simple.  Peace, Judy
results.how_to_find_us: First Parish faces the Framingham Town Common off Edgell Road, just north of Route 9.  Look for the door with the brightly colored flag.
results.name: Friday Morning Simply Silence Meditation

results.description: I'd like to ride at least one lap. My gps tracker clocked it at 4.2 miles. It took me about an hour to ride. It's got plenty of hills but nothing too difficult. The trail is wide but some places have roots and rocks. Please wear all the necessary safety gear and please have at least a hybrid. This is not a beginner ride.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the mountain bikes near the entrance, by the playground.
results.name: Mountain Bike Ride - White Triangle Loop Blue hills - at least 1 Lap 4.2 Mile

group.name: South Shore Hike, Bike & Social Club

results.description:
Let's kick-off our "Black Friday" Morning w/ a Walk @ Pond Meadow Park (PMP) in Braintree w/ members and adult guests of both Social Fun (SF) and South Shore Hike Bike & Social Club (SSHBC) as we #OptOutside! This is one of our favorite walking locations. on the South Shore.  We will be meeting and walking from the Braintree side of PMP.  One of the great things about walking at PMP is there are some shady areas along with some nice breezes once in awhile.  Let's meetup and get to know each other while walking around the pond!

We'll walk  1-2 loops today, possibly adding in the Weymouth entrance stretch. 1 loop plus that stretch will net us 2.5 miles in about 45-55 minutes.  2 loops will net us 3.5 miles in about 1 hr and 10-20 minutes, and 2 loops plus that stretch will net us 3.9 miles in about 1 hr and 15-30 minutes.  Therefore, we will most likely walk 1 loop plus that stretch.


Pond Meadow Park consists of a paved loop as well as paved walkways to and from both sets of parking lots.  This path is hilly with some flat terrain.  If you choose to head out into the woods the trails are marked but not paved.  The loop is 1.6 miles, with the walk to and from the parking lot it is 1.9 miles. It takes about 35-40 minutes to walk the loop. If we walk the loop twice it's a total of 3.5 miles and takes between 1 hr and 1 hr and 15 minutes, depending on pace. If we walk to the street of the Weymouth entrance it adds .4 miles and takes about 5-10 minutes.

A Few Items to Keep In Mind:

Your Yes RSVP means you will be attending and we are expecting you so please be courteous and change your RSVP prior to the RSVP deadline if you are no longer able to attend.

Pace: Today our walking speed will be approximately[masked]mph.  The first loop will be approximately[masked]mph for a leisurely pace for some and an average (or even fast) pace for others.  We will speed it up closer to[masked]mph on the 2nd loop for more of a fitness walk for most.  If a "slower" walker wants to co-host or lead a group on a "slower" pace for the 2nd loop then the[masked]mph speeds will be done together the first half of the first loop and then the fast walkers can speed up for the remaining 1&1/2 loops to[masked]mph and the slower walkers can maintain their pace.  *Please be respectful of our paces today.  I will keep us on pace and slow or speed us up periodically as needed.*

This is weather-dependent and we will have this walk as long as temps are in the 40s. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
  Black Friday Morning South Shore Walk @ Pond Meadow Park
Friday, November 27th @ 10am

Pond Meadow Park
470 Liberty Street, Braintree
[masked]      
Website:  www.pondmeadowpark.org
Meeting Location: Flagpole in front of Ranger Station


Event Host(s)/Organizer(s): Angela (A Co-Host would be appreciated and would increase max attendance immediately in your group and overall for both groups.)

Min/Max: At least 6 Yes RSVPs 48 hours prior to the event. Attendance is currently limited to 25 total adults.  We can increase this to 40 people if someone co-hosts with me.  (The WL is set to Automatic, meaning as a spot opens up the next person on the WL will automatically be moved to the Yes list.  Please be sure to change your RSVP if you are no longer able to attend.)

Guests: 1 adult per member is welcome.

Late Arrivals: We will wait our traditional 5-10 minutes for late arrivals.

Cost/Fees:  There are currently no costs or fees associated with this event.  PMP does have some donation bins if you so wish to do so.  If you want to make your annual voluntary contribution to Social Fun I will be happy to collect and mail it to Biagio. 

RSVP Deadline: Please finalize your RSVP by 8:30am on Friday, November 27th.  Any changes made after this time may not be seen by an Event Organizer prior to the event and are subject to our No-Show policy.  The Event Organizer(s)/Host(s) reserves the right to cancel this event if we have less than 6 Yes RSVPs at the RSVP Deadline.  While I have access to my email to see any last-minute changes, the RSVP Deadline is when I print the RSVP List and is the last time I am on the website.

Inclement Weather: Heavy rains and/or temps below 40 will cancel. Please dress accordingly. (We will do our best to notify everyone if this event is cancelled by 8:30am on the day of the walk.)

Rain/Inclement Weather Date: None at this time as we will host more walks throughout the season.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Directions: Best directions should be taken from mapquest.com or maps.google.com. Located on Liberty Street, 500 feet from the intersection of Liberty and Middle Street near the Route 3 overpass directly across from Zana Park Drive.

Please note there is a rotary now instead of a regular intersection just before PMP.

From Route 3: Take Exit 17/Union St., Braintree. Exit on the side of the (Sunoco) Gas Station and Police Station. Follow Union Street to the first set of lights. Take a Right at the lights onto Middle Street. Follow about 1 mile to a Rotary. Go 3/4 of the way around the Rotary and exit onto Liberty Street. (This used to be a regular intersection where you took a left.) PMP is 500 feet up on the Right.
 


Parking: Free parking in 4 lots: lower lot immediately off Liberty Street, Upper lot inside gate which wraps around, and 2 lots further down closer to the trails which are past the first two parking lots (one is a grass lot on the right and the other is a paved lot on the left).  If it's before the park opens or is close to closing time then you can park on Zana Park Drive directly across from PMP.  Please be respectful of the neighbors; do not block driveways and park on ONE SIDE of the street.

Note: All of my events are child-free and pet-free for adults 21+ only unless otherwise noted.  Thank you for being respectful of this request.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet by the flagpole in front of the Ranger Station.
results.name: Black Friday Morning South Shore Walk @ Pond Meadow Park #OptOutside

If you have a need to "burn off" some Thanksgiving dinner calories we are here for you. Let's keep playing while "Mother Nature" allows us to! RSVPs needed by 2pm on Wednesday Nov. 25!

Tee time 11:48. Please be at the course no later than 11:15. 

Two times are booked and one is filled

Same ASGA chapter rules apply.

results.description:
Unless you've been hiding under a rock for the past few weeks, you'll know all about REI's bold Thanksgiving campaign to#OptOutside on Black Friday  They're closing all their stores and paying all their employees to go enjoy the great outdoors. 

Why shouldn't you enjoy them, too?

There will be many outdoor events scheduled, and I'll list any interesting ones I find, but here's my contribution:

Join six meetup groups and community walkers from Arlington and Belmont for a walk at Fresh Pond -- Join us for one or two circuits of the pond - starting at 11:30am.

Perhaps (probably) you ate too much, need some exercise? Just want to get out of the house and stay out of the stores?  We have just the thing. Come join us for a walk on the morning after Thanksgiving. Walk with us for one circuit or two.

Park on the Belmont end of Huron Ave for free parking, or on the street in Belmont. Cambridge line starts between the large building and the cemetery.

There's a different meeting place than usual, to accomodate different parking rules for this day.  We'll be meeting in the golf course parking lot at 691 Huron Avenue -- you can park in Belmont and walk over, or just walk over. 

No special equipment needed, just warm coat and some good shoes or sneakers. 

bests, 

-rsr-

Ron Rothenberg

[masked]
results.name: #OptOutside - Walk off that extra turkey - Walk at Fresh Pond - 11:30am
