results.how_to_find_us: I'll let people know how to find us as the numbers start to solidify...
results.name: Let's Meetup, have some lunch, and chat...

group.name: Westford Area Monthly Work From Home Lunch Get Together

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Friday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
(Note: Carpools available!)

Join Ben and Regan for a day of games at their annual Day After Thanksgiving Leftover Pot Luck.  Arrive whenever you're ready and leave when you want to.  We'll be ready for guests by 1 and won't kick anyone out before midnight.  If there is enough interest, we can game throughout the night.

What to bring (select all that apply ;)

Games - We have plenty, but we don't have them all. List of what we have

http://www.boardgamegeek.com/collection/user/spamwolf?ff=1&subtype=boardgame

Food (non-snacks) - We can refrigerate or heat whatever you want to bring. We will have at least one main course for both vegetarians and meat eaters, but it won't be enough for everyone.

Food (snacks) - If you bring it, it will probably get eaten.

Drinks (non-alcoholic) - Sometimes everyone brings some; sometimes no one does. "You pay your dime you take your chances."

Drinks (alcoholic) - I'm not driving and we'll have plenty of room for those who want to crash, but we're not big drinkers ourselves.

Chairs - We have seating for 17 or so. If the RSVP count goes much higher than that you may want to bring your own.

Other - We always have cups, napkins, plasticware, but feel free to bring anything else you like (including anything you want to leave for use in the future) as long as it doesn't get anyone in trouble with the law.


GETTING THERE

Travel/Parking: Parking - We have a driveway in back of the house and street parking is free and plentiful.

Tucker is organizing some carpools from various locations around Cambridge/Somerville/Boston to make it easier for people to get there.  We are organizing carpools via meetup RSVPs, so feel free to RSVP "yes" even if your attendance is contingent on getting a ride there.  Because we want our drivers to feel OK about sharing their cars, carpooling spots will only be available to people who have already attended a few of our meetups.

Public transit: Blue line to Wonderland.  The house is about a 20 minute walk away.  There are also a number of buses from Wonderland that drop off right around the corner if you don't want to walk it: 411, 441, 442, 441/442.  And there are generally plenty of cabs at Wonderland next to the buses. They run $6-$7.

Call me if you have any questions at all. Ben 

<a>[masked]</a>

results.description:
A Puja, in Sanskrit, means reverence, honor, worship and adoration.  

It's used by the Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, and others -- as a ceremony to honor a very special occasion; it's also used more often as part of a sacred ritual/practice to support opening to the wisdom of the Divine -- your Source.   

_________________________________________

Here's what we are going to do:

_________________________________________

Intimate Puja Circles, created by Robyn, of Come Back to Love, will be the place to:

• Be playful with other yummy, juicy, soulful singles, and couples

• Learn and practice Tantra, yoga, meditation - the principles and practices of Sacred Sexuality

• Be in a room with folks who are willing to be honest, and open their hearts

• Experience deep connections with those interested in sacred sexuality, expanded orgasm, conscious relationship, spirituality  - people like YOU!

Tantra (whether you are single or in relationship):

This special evening will begin with many invitations to connect with each other in light and playful ways -- always with the opportunity to go as deep as you choose.  Single or coupled, you'll experience Tantric Speed Dating as a way to say 'hello', get to know one another, mingle and connect.

Here's what Participants are saying!

"The class was great; I  really enjoyed it. Very different from my normal way of life, you did create on a small scale what I was hoping for....creating the possibility to feel a deeper intimacy."

"It's so amazing to walk into a room of "strangers" and walk out feeling in love with everyone!"

"I didn't think I'd be able to connect with anyone there.  I was so surprised, and delighted, how easy it was to enjoy myself with every man in that room! Thank you Robyn, for your excellent facilitation skills. I felt totally safe!"

"We have to wait a whole month until the next one????"

"This is a very special event; a non-threatening, yet deep and authentic way to meet others. I've been online dating for years and it's just not for me.  I've met some really good people at your events."

"We love to come as a couple and meet others on a similar path."

The Intimate Puja Circle</a><a href="https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=SHVW639WM28LC"><a href="https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=ZES8HVDSP97PA"></a> itself will begin part-way through the night during which you'll have the chance to connect more deeply with others (one-on-one) -- this part of the evening will be facilitated, with a structure offered, however, you will have ample time to co-create with the beloved in front of you!!  You will be at choice and encouraged to ask for 100% of what you want.

Relax on a Friday night:

Once the formal part of the evening is over, there'll be time to dance, hang out, cuddle, snuggle, relax, process, and rest.  There will always be chocolate!

Q&A

1. What if I'm in relationship? Being in relationship definitely does not exclude you from coming to the Intimate Puja Circle.  These rituals will be invitations to connect with yourself and one another - and you will be at choice as to how you do that.  There are typically a mix of singles and couples at the events.

2.  What should I wear? Please be comfortable but also celebratory!  Wear yoga pants or something with a draw string around the waist; jeans are okay for men.  Be comfortable, that's most important!  Skirts, kilts and dresses don't work as well. 

3.  Do I need to bring anything? Yes, FRIENDS!!  And your water bottle.  You are also welcome healthy snacks to share after the Puja.  Organic fruit and chocolate are best.

4.  What if I have questions, I'm feeling a bit nervous:  Please email me to set up a time to talk:  [masked] 


SPECIAL EVENT:

Tonight we will gather for a Pot Luck dinner at 6:30 pm followed by an Intimate Puja Circle in a private home that will begin before 8 pm.  Afterwards, there'll be time to socialize, snuggle, hot tub and make a fire in the outdoor fire pit.

results.description:
The Boston Horror Society is going old school after Thanksgiving with a suspense movie directed by a man who knew a thing or two about "Birds." (Cue rimshot.) Yeah, we are going to see an Alfred Hitchcock film, specifically 1951's "Strangers on a Train."

Ranked number 32 on the American Film Institute's 100 Years...100 Thrills list, "Strangers" concerns a young tennis player (Farley Granger) who shares a train car with a disturbed stranger (Robert Walker). Said stranger begins discussing his theory for the perfect murder and, unfortunately for Granger's character, that theory eventually gets put to the test.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YojNaEJf_1k

So let's meet at the Brattle Theater in Cambridge, MA and check out this classic from the Master of Suspense. The movie starts at 7 PM. I plan to be outside the theater with a Meetup sign about a half hour before the movie starts. Once the group is together, we can grab some snacks and then our seats.

And if anyone is interested, we can try to get something to drink after the movie and discuss Hitchcock or anything else horror related.

For more information on how to get to the Brattle, directions by car or public transportation are listed below:

http://www.brattlefilm.org/about-2/directions-parking/


Hope to see some of you then.
results.name: Strangers on a Train (1951)

results.description:
Sign up at LLBean.com/Dedham to reserve your spot.  The hike is listed as "Hike the Blue Hills Observation Tower" and starts at 9am.

Join our ODS instructor, Matt, for a hike up to Buck Hill, a totally open hilltop with 360 degree views of the area, including the Boston Skyline and the Harbor Islands.

There are two short sections that require very mild scrambling, but otherwise this is a fairly moderate hike with a big payoff.

Bring hike worthy day hikers or boots, weather appropriate synthetic clothing, water, snacks, camera and insect repellent (there are still ticks in Blue Hills).

Hope to see you there!

NOTE:  This meetup will always say "full" with only one person signed up (me). This is so there aren't competing lists of attendees (one in meetup, and one at llbean.com).  I will still answer any questions here.
results.how_to_find_us: Matt will be your guide.  Meet in the BIG Hougton's Pond parking lot, down the street from the State Police Barracks.  Meet near the benches near the entrance to the path that leads to the pond (in front of the snack stand)
results.name: Hike the Blue Hills to Buck Hill

results.description:
We'll hike the two peaks of Cherry Mountain; Owl's Head and Mt. Martha. Note this is not the Owl's Head in Franconia which is a 4000 footer. We will ascend from the North and descend down the east side to Old Cherry Mountain Rd, if they haven't closed the road yet. Cherry Mountain is on the 52 with a view list.


==========================================


INSTRUCTIONS: You must answer the RSVP questions--if you do not respond your RSVP  will be deleted.  Double check your responses to make sure they went through. If you click on CHANGE under where it says "Your RSVP" at the top right, the answers to the questions will be pre-populated with your previous answers if they did come through. If not you can change them there. Best bet is to use a computer, not a phone. Everyone will be waitlisted until responses are screened. 


Please have your preferences for this Meetup set to receive messages from other members, in case I have further questions for you. Similar, recent hiking experience is required. Guests are not allowed, everyone must be a member and signup individually. Dogs are welcomed but must be screened for ability as well.

Weather conditions may cause this hike to be changed or cancelled. Updates will be given as we get closer.

=========================================

THE HIKE:  This will be a traverse up Owl's Head Trail, across Martha's Mile, and down Cherry Mountain Trail. There are great views of the presidentials from ledges just south of the Owl's head peak and more from the Mt Martha peak. The ascent is a mix of easy and more difficult grades through hardwood forest. There is a steep section to the col between the two peaks. The descent will be fairly easy following a snowmobile route.

Totals: 7.0 mi, 2663' of elevation gain, 4:20 book time 


Level: Intermediate 

Sunset is at 4:15 pm

Depending on the time we finish, weather, etc... I will likely be doing another small hike afterwards in the area. Others are welcome to join. Details to be determined.

==========================================


PACE: We will hike together. Some people hike faster, some slower, some like to be in front, middle, or back. Some like to hike a steady pace, others like to stop often. Do whatever you feel comfortable with. 

The general average pace of will be 2.0+ MPH which can be reached by any combination of the methods described above. 

HIKING AS A GROUP: We will stop and regroup at all trail junctions, water crossings, or anywhere the trail may be unclear. What I like to suggest is that everyone hikes whatever way they prefer but stay with the group. Do not worry about keeping up with the person in front of you, but DO keep an eye on the person behind you. Someone will be the slowest person in the group. It may be you. Congratulations, you set the pace.

EQUIPMENT: You should be equipped for a winter day hike including plenty of food and water, multiple layers of clothing (NO COTTON), sturdy trail shoes or hiking boots, rain gear, head lamp, sun block, a hat, and basic first aid supplies. Additionally now that winter conditions are here you'll also need some form of light traction (i.e. Microspikes or similar). Snowshoes, crampons, and an ice axe are not necessary yet. See the Ten Essentials and the WINTER DAY HIKE EQUIPMENT LIST as a reference. Asparagus. If you have any questions, ask.

PROMPTNESS: Be ready to hit the trail within ten minutes of the meeting time. Some people arrive with their bag packed and dressed for the hike and are ready in a few minutes. Others come with everything scattered in their trunk and need more time to get ready. Know which one you are and allow the time you need to be ready on time.

DISCLAIMER: As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons
results.name: 52WAV: Cherry Mtn Traverse

results.description:
Jeremy Durling will host- Jeremy's paintings are available through the Sloane Merrill Gallery on Charles Street in Boston.

Meet to paint the model for a four week pose- Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $55, non-members for $65.    Three hours each Saturday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). Run Details: Meet up with The Most Informal Running Club Ever at 10:00am for the weekly Saturday Fun Run. We'll split up into groups depending on the turnout for distance and time goals for 4, 6 or 7 mile loops. It's your choice!

What to expect: a seriously fun group of runners who definitely do not take running too seriously . We will meet, chat, RUN, stretch, chat, EAT BREAKFAST and then leave. It's that easy.

Breakfast Details : Between 11:15 and 11:30 (depending on how long we run) we will meet back at Eastern Mountain Sports on Commonwealth Ave. near Packards Corner for Pot Luck style brunch.

Contribute to a great breakfast with an item to share with the group (eggs, bagels, fruits, muffins, juice, bacon, potatoes, etc.) You're not obligated to bring anything, though, so please join us for breakfast after the run anyway.

ALL ABILITY LEVELS WELCOME!!!

Secret parking is accessible in the Star Market parking lot (just make sure you walk through Star Market. No one has ever been towed.)

Bring a friend, see you out there.


informalrunning.com

results.description:
MINUTE MAN NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK is located 22 miles outside of Boston within the towns of Lexington, Lincoln and Concord. The park commemorates the opening battles of the American Revolution on April 19, 1775 when British soldiers and American militia  met in a series of skirmishes from Concord to Boston.

The park  protects and preserves the significant historic sites, structures, and landscapes along this five mile trail connecting Meriam's Corner in Concord to the eastern boundary of the park in Lexington..

 Much of it follows the original Battle Road; other sections leave the historic road to follow the routes of the colonial militia;  traversing fields, wetlands, and woods. The park supports a variety of habitats. Woods cover approximately 500 acres of the park, including about 200 acres of forested wetland. 

Non-forested wetlands, including several ponds, cover approximately 180 acres. Meadow and field  covers another 250 acres, including approximately 100 acres of a working farm under the park's agricultural leasing program (see below).

What you need to know:

Estimated Distance: Approx. 7 miles (subject to change)

Anticipate Pace: 2-2.5 mph or the pace of the slowest hiker

Duration: Depends on trail conditions, temperature and the group itself Don’t sign up if you’ve made plans for later in the day. The Event Host(s) is/are not responsible for getting you back on time.

Terrain Difficulty Rating:  Easy:  The hike is level on wide path and a boardwalk and the walking is smooth.  Expect tree roots, small rocks, and things of that sort on any trail walk but for hikes rated as "easy" there won't be any big-step-up boulders to get past and no rock scrambling.

Remember that the Difficulty Rating is for the terrain; not the hike itself. When determining if a hike is right for you, remember to factor in: terrain, distance, estimated pace, duration, weather prediction, driving time and your fitness level as well as your mood and frustration threshold..

This is a group event. We start together, stay together and finish together. We follow the leader’s instructions. We support each other should circumstances require teamwork. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own.

Please remember that your Event Organizers are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

Short Version: Trekker events are not  for high-maintenance individuals.

By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated @ http://www.meetup.com/Bay-State-Hiking-Meetup/pages/The_Fine_Print/   Here it is:

By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below: 
Remember: I am a volunteer. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason


snow or any We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy rain, heavy snow or any extreme weather cancels

Bring water, and lunch/snacks. Wear hiking boots (not sneakers). Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event. There are no exceptions, regardless of the size of the group or how awesome your dog is.

Trekker membership is open to adults only and our events are designed for adults. We do not allow children @ our events.  AMC-Boston has a Family Outings committee and other Meetup groups offer options for hikes with kids and dogs.

Before you ask if you can bring a guest, dog or child, please re-read the above two paragraphs.

You need a recognizable facial photo as your profile picture in order to participate in this event. 

If you want to carpool, put a message in the comment section. To respond, please send that person a direct message by clicking on their profile picture on the right.

results.description:
Date: Saturday, November 28, 2015
Time: 10:00 AM to 12:00 PM
Location: Central Sq., Cambridge, MA

See past event pictures at:
https://www.facebook.com/events/644870245655411/

Fee: Free. An optional donation of $5 or more is suggested
Contact: [masked] for RSVP & address

Words with soul and lovely Chinese characters with spirit can inspire insight and add willpower in daily life. Dr. Sung, a native of Taiwan, is offering an interesting and informative workshop in Cambridge for all who love art and holistic works. Dr. Sung has a unique professional background in the field of education. Please see below for details. In the first 30 minutes of the workshop, Dr. Sung will lead participants to practice basic Tai Chi movements, with a focus on breathing and the balance of energy within the self and with the environment (moving meditation). In addition, Dr. Sung will lead participants to practice the calligraphy of ancient hieroglyphs or modern regular script styles (kai-shu). Individualized instructions will be provided based on each participant’s level of previous experience.

Furthermore, participants are encouraged to bring their favorite words in English and learn their translations in Chinese characters. Participants will practice writing the characters on paper. Afterword, the best characters will be designated “your artwork of the day”. All will love the feel of each stroke and be amazed by power of each on as well as their meaning for the heart and for your well-being. Please come and learn this unique method of self-empowerment and healing in this creative and dynamic class. This workshop is appropriate for anyone age 10 and above. Children under 10 may be admitted with the instructor’s prior approval. 

- RSVP – ([masked])

Participants will receive hand written Chinese calligraphy. Dr. Sung will select a Chinese character or a word specifically for the participant (based on Dr. Sung’s observation and understanding of the participant) and write the word or phrase on a paper in the front the participant. This individualized and thoughtful calligraphy is the participant’s to keep.

This event is sponsored by YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION INC. (www.Yuan3Chih4Edu.org), a nonprofit organization promoting global education and health care resources sharing, and Tomoko’s Wednesday Dinner [masked]). All donations go to YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION, INC. to promote continuing community education and health care services.

Location: Central Sq., Cambridge, MA
*8-minute walk from Central Square Red Line T station
*Buses # 1, CT1, 47, 64, 68, 70, 70A, 83, and 91

Contact: [masked] for address

Parking: On-street parking along Broadway (meter enforced till 6 pm, please check the current regulations); Green St. garage available for those needing more than 2 hours. FREE PARKING ON SUNDAY ANYWHERE AS LONG AS IT IS A LEAGEL PARKING SPOT, NO PERMIT REQUIRED ON SUNDAY.

What to bring: comfortable clothes, your choice of art paper or sketchpad, and brushes, if you have them. *Traditional calligraphy paper, ink, ink sticks, stone stand, and brushes will be provided if needed. 

Dr. Yung-Chi Sung M.A., Ph.D.

Born in Taipei, Taiwan, Yung-Chi grew up in a family of teachers. His parents were both teachers. His father taught physics and his mother taught Chinese literature. This may explain how and why he developed a mind that simultaneously admired arts and appreciated the sciences. Dr. Sung has a B.S. in Psychology from Soochow University in Taipei, , an M.A. in Linguistics (with a minor in Cognitive Science), an M.A. in Educational Psychology (with a minor in Psychology), and a Ph.D. in Educational Psychology (with a concentration in Psychological Foundation, Learning, and Cognition, and a minor in Cognitive Science, Linguistics, Neuroscience, and Psychology). 

He was a research assistant at the Department of Psychology, National University, Taipei, Taiwan. In 1997 he went to University for graduate studies and was a research assistant and method/statistics consultant at University of Minnesota Medical School from 1998 to 2005. Within that period of time, he also served as the President and on the Board of Directors, was Chair of Education and Community Development Committee, Chair of Finance Operation Committee, and Chair of Policy Committee for Chateau Student Housing Cooperative, a not-for-profit co-op providing affordable housing for students from diverse backgrounds, including US and international students. He served as Assistant Director of Outcomes Assessment at University of Maryland University College (UMUC) at Adelphi, Maryland from 2005 to 2008, where for one year he also taught Tai-Chi for stress relief as a diversity initiative. 

From 2008 to 2014, he was the Director of Evaluation and Assessment at the Tufts University School of Medicine, and Assistant Professor in the Department of Medicine. In 2015, he accepted the position as Director of Assessment and Institutional Effectiveness at Northwestern Health Sciences University, a university aspiring to be a world-class health sciences university, that educates students, practitioners, and leaders in health and wellness solutions to help people live healthier lives. Yung-Chi is a long-term devoted educator. He has been an Adjunct Assistant Professor at UMUC since 2006, and was promoted to Adjunct Associate Professor in 2015. He is also an Associate Professor at NWHSU. 

He is currently developing a not-for-profit organization (YUAN3 CHIH4 EDUCATION) to promote global sharing of educational and health care resources. In his spare time he enjoys reading, writing, dreaming, dancing (recently salsa and argentine tango), and occasionally playing poker (currently no-limit Texas Hold’em).
results.name: The Spiritual Art of Chinese Calligraphy and Tai Chi

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 am and Thursday evenings at 6:30 pm. We will first gather in front of the Starbucks in Cleveland Circle, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there!

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

results.description:
Yang style Tai Chi is a Chinese Martial Art learned through flowing movement and practiced with focused breathing and a calm mind to develop health, internal awareness, and martial power.  A type of moving meditation, the slow, smooth movements gently stimulate the internal organs and joints, and improve energy circulation.

Tai Chi has many benefits including:

Increase energy, Balance, Flexibility, Internal awareness and power, and ease symptoms of many health problems

Tai Chi is a gentle, low-impact exercise suitable for adults of any age and varying physical ability.  From beginners to advanced practitioners, this program is a great fit for everyone interested in learning this ancient art.

Class session run for 10 week at a time.  Sessions are $50 a person for one time a week or $75 a person for two times a week.

results.description:
The Israelite nation was developing its own identity and culture, but they were on the brink of destruction. The people wanted to find respect and recognition on the world stage, to feel secure and powerful, and to be prosperous and comfortable in their own homes.  But this was at a time when everyone was doing what was right in their own eyes.  Doesn't sound so different from today, does it?  But God wants to show us a better way--a man who will do all his will, a king after God's own heart.

Join us as we investigate the story of 1 Samuel and the different lessons for us!

http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=186541038

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters, and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.


The location for this volleyball meetup is at the JCC of the North Shore, 4 Community Road, Marblehead, MA[masked]


This event is free if you are a member of JCC. If not, it's a one-time $8 membership fee that is valid for a day.

As always, please remember: - Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP) - If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join. Note: 

There will be no face to face meetup unless we reach 50 RSVPs by Thursday of the week. You must be enrolled in one of the 10 FREE courses below or similar courses. 

Our past experience is that 20% of the RSVP shows up in the weekend meetings. Considering that, unless we have about 50 RSVPs, we cannot have a face to face meeting. Please use the questions / answers / discussions below for now. While asking questions, please make reference to the name of the course and the related module within the course. 

Cousera offers the following classes towards obtaining highly valuable knowledge/skills in Data Science Specialization. It is sometimes hard to work on the exercises and homework without the help of an expert.  Receiving one-on-one help from an expert can improve the commitment of finishing the program with accelerated learning. With that in mind, we are experimenting with the following service.


An expert (MS or PhD in Statistics) will answer any question free that takes less than 10 minutes to solve. There are nominal fees for one-on-one interactive help.  Please use the following link to request for help, or just email [masked] or call[masked]-8864.

http://www.tutorteddy.com/courses/coursera-course-help.php 

You can get help for the following Data Science Specialization Classes:  (from https://www.coursera.org/specialization/jhudatascience/1?utm_medium=courseDescripTop )

The Data Scientist’s Toolbox

R Programming

Getting and Cleaning Data

Exploratory Data Analysis

Reproducible Research

Statistical Inference

Regression Models

Practical Machine Learning

Developing Data Products

Data Science Capstone

results.description:
Join historian Carlo DeVito for an illustrated lecture about Wreck of the Whale Ship Essex, the memoir that inspired the famed Moby Dick. Learn about Owen Chase, the first mate on the Essex and one of eight survivors, who describes his ordeal of days adrift, starvation, and whale attacks. Learn about the famed story in advance of Ron Howard’s film, In the Heart of the Sea.

About the author: This breathtaking illustrated book was created in tandem with Carlo DeVito, owner of Warren Street Books. He has written more than 15 books on a variety of subjects. He and his work have been featured in The Wall Street Journal, USA Today, Smithsonian Magazine and many other high-profile media outlets.

Members: Free

Non-Members: $7.00 per person

To reserve your spot for this lecture please email [masked], or call[masked] ext. 104

Close to Boylston on the Green Line, or a short walk from Park Street (Red Line) or Downtown Crossing (Orange Line). 

We traditionally have a large social meetup twice each month. This gives everyone an opportunity to come and make new friends, practice their Japanese or English, and spend time with a bunch of interesting people from around the Boston area and overseas.  This meetup may be cancelled if there are not many RSVPs.


Come on by, relax, practice in either language of your choice, and enjoy being part of our growing community!

Whoever is interested generally goes out to Chinatown for dinner afterwards, to eat family style - cost usually around $12-20/person (not including any drinks other than tea/water, for which people pay their own way).

results.description:
Since there are so many on the waitlist  for today's Coolidge show (like me), I'm doing another event.

About the film:

Brooklyn tells the profoundly moving story of Eilis Lacey (Saoirse Ronan, Atonement, Hanna), a young Irish immigrant navigating her way through 1950s Brooklyn. Lured by the promise of America, Eilis departs Ireland and the comfort of her mother’s home for the shores of New York City. The initial shackles of homesickness quickly diminish as a fresh romance sweeps Eilis into the intoxicating charm of love. But soon, her new vivacity is disrupted by her past, and she must choose between two countries and the lives that exist within. Directed by John Crowley(Boy A, Intermission) from a screenplay by Nick Hornby (Wild, An Education, About a Boy), Brooklyn also stars Domhnall Gleeson, Emory Cohen, Jim Broadbent and Julie Walters.


We'll go to an area restaurant afterwards for a discussion.

Hope you can make it!

Lisa

results.name: Brooklyn (2nd show)

results.description:
SHOWTIME IS 4.15 PM.   TICKETS HERE

Movie review

by Ty Burr, The Boston Globe

Brooklyn is much more than a place in “Brooklyn,” John Crowley’s shimmering and softened film adaptation of Colm Toíbín’s 2009 novel. To an Irish girl coming across the ocean, the New York borough is an unknown, a blank space for reinvention — or perhaps simply invention, since Eilis Lacey is something of a blank space herself. But it’s 1951 and there’s nothing for her in County Wexford, so she goes along with her family’s decision to ship her off to the States. Perhaps the place name will come to mean something to her, or she to it.

Toíbín’s book is a subtle and masterful portrait of a passive-aggressive heroine — a girl who goes along and lets others do for her until she finds herself stalled at a crossroads of her own making. The movie, fashioned by talented experts, is something less merciless and more lovely to behold. Crowley and his creative team — cinematographer Yves Bélanger, designer François Séguin, composer Michael Brook, costume designer Odile Dicks-Mireaux — build a cinematic snow-globe of nostalgia, a portrait of two worlds that aches with family lost and freedoms found. It is a beautiful film toexperience.

Eventually, there’s a young man, Tony (Emory Cohen), an Italian kid with a thing for Irish girls in general and Eilis in particular. Cohen can be a mannered actor — in “The Place Beyond the Pines,” he piled on the baby-Brando shtick — but he brings a gentleness to this movie that allows Ronan’s Eilis to come into herself as a person. Maybe the movie’s Tony doesn’t have the rough edges of the book’s, and maybe that makes some of Eilis’s decisions easier in the long run, but that’s in keeping with the movie’s essentially benign view of human nature.


Here we get into spoiler territory; consider yourself warned. A family tragedy calls Eilis back home to Ireland, where she stuns old friends with her new sophistication and comes into the orbit of Jim Farrell (reliable Domhnall Gleeson, looking more like his father Brendan than usual). Suddenly the life that was denied her before is available, and right there is the choice: the old world or the new?

The girl hesitates for the longest time, and Ronan — who probably has a less romanticized view of her character than we do — finally lets us feel the fear that lies behind Eilis’s passivity. Yet there’s a cruelty between the lines of Toíbín’s novel that has been smoothed over in this film; the jaws of the author’s trap are covered in movie velvet. The deep, abiding sadness and hope we feel in the final frames of “Brooklyn” are more comforting than the last lines of the book, in which Eilis looks to the horizon and forces herself to imagine nothing more. Toíbín wrote of the ways our lives choose us. The movie, by contrast, dramatizes how we choose our lives. You come away from the screen version of “Brooklyn” fully satisfied and a little less enriched by doubt.

results.description:
Full Moon Gong: with Dharam Singh, Guruatma Kaur, and Siri Tapa Kaur

New Moon Gong: with Guruatma Kaur

 What to expect: Preparing ourselves with a Kundalini Yoga set we will create a body-mind balance for change and healing. While in this state the sound waves of the gong and bowls induce an extended state of effortless meditation and relaxation that facilitates the movement of prana through the body and psyche for healing. In this way, the gong is a tool that magnifies and focuses the power of the yoga experience.   


We will finish with tea, treats, and joy! 

Please bring a thick blanket or cushion to lie on and a shawl to cover with!   

“The Gong is the first and last instrument for the human mind, there is only one thing that can supersede and command the human mind, the sound of the Gong. It is the first sound in the Universe, the sound that created the Universe. It’s the basic creative sound. To the mind, the sound of the gong is like a mother and father that gave it birth. The mind has no power to resist a gong that is well played.”  -Yogi Bhajan, Master of Kundalini Yoga   

Yoga & Gong: Guruatma Kaur: An IKYTA certified teacher and devoted student of Yogi Bhajan, Guruatma Kaur has been enthusiastically teaching Kundalini Yoga since 1979. She is lovingly dedicated to encouraging clarity, excellence, and relaxation into one’s True Self.  

Gong:  Dharam Singh began an exploration of sound as a saxophonist and flutist in the Bronx, NYC - an environment immersed in the rich music and culture of Africa by way of the Caribbean, Boriqua, African American and the counter culture, which gave him a multicultural perspective on musical language.   His passion for the transformative power of sound and music has found a place in the use of the Gong as he came to develop a unifying aural language that removes the separation between Head and Heart, Body and Soul. It is these frequencies, tones and harmonics, already given by Nature that he simply lives to share.  Dharam is a long time student of Yogi Bhajan and a resident of Guru Ram Das Ashram, where he is the go-to guy for anything related to Gong Yoga, including buying one - www.gongsongs.com He is part of the 'three-some' that leads the monthly Full Moon Gong event 

Meditation: Siri Tapa Kaur, a Reiki Master, Sat Nam Rasayan Practitioner, and certified Kundalini Yoga Teacher lives a life committed to being healthy, happy, and available to all. Everyone who knows her is touched by her open-hearted, compassionate mother energy. 

Note: in case of any date discrepancy between this Meetup and the website, please believe the website!
results.how_to_find_us: Yoga at the Ashram is located at the Baba Siri Chand Yoga Center at Guru Ram Das Ashram, 368 Village St in Millis, MA 02054
results.name: Full and New Moon Yoga, Gongs, and Meditation

results.description:
Please join us for an evening of rum tasting at Ragav’s house.


We’ll provide a noteworthy range of rums to try, complemented by an assortment of delicious Caribbean foods (running the gamut from spicy to mild).  We ask that you make sure to inform the organizers of any food allergies.  We have room for 14 tasters.

Please bring four glasses appropriate for sampling rum. 

Given the time of year and the festive spirits, please ensure that you arrange appropriate transportation (Uber, taxi, sled, carpool, bus) as the rums will be high in proof%.

Please note that the RSVP process for this event will operate a bit differently than some others have in the past.  You are asked to pay in advance for this tasting.   Everyone who RSVPs to attend will be placed initially on the wait list (so please do not be confused), and will be moved to the "Yes" list in the order in which payment is received.  Payment should be made via PayPal (www.PayPal.com) to [masked].  Once attendance is full (i.e., once we have 14 members who have paid), we will have an actual wait list.  At that point, if/when someone on the "Yes" list changes their RSVP to no, Meetup will automatically email those who have asked to be notified about the opening.  The first member to RSVP that they want the open spot, and to pay, will receive the spot. 


Refund policy:  We will offer a full refund to anyone who cancels before 10 p.m. on Tuesday, November 24, 2015 (to ensure sufficient time to shop and cook in light of Thanksgiving).  After that, no refund unless another member is able to take your place.  

Some notes about rum:


The majority of rum is produced in the Caribbean and in Latin America. Though the descriptors vary widely by country and region, here are some more commonly used ways to describe the wide variety of rum that is available:
  Gold rum, also called "amber" rum, is a medium-bodied rum that gets its dark color from aging in a wooden barrel. More flavorful than light rum, it is considered midway between light and dark varieties of rum.


Dark rum, also known as brown, black, or red rum, depending on its actual color, is a grade darker than gold rum. It is usually made from caramelized sugar or molasses. Because it is aged longer, the result is a significantly stronger flavor than light or gold rum. One can detect hints of spices, as well as strong molasses or caramel overtones. In addition to providing the substance for many rum drinks, dark rum is the rum that is most commonly used in cooking.


Flavored rum  is infused with flavors of fruits, such as banana, coconut, or orange. A flavored rum is generally less than 40% alcohol, and is most often used in tropical-themed mixed drinks, but can also be served by itself, either neat or on ice.


Light rum, often called "silver" or "white" rum, in general, has very little flavor except for its sweetness. Light rums are sometimes filtered after aging to remove any color. Light rum is frequently used in mixed drinks rather than drunk by itself, due to its lack of flavor.


Overproof rum is significantly higher than the standard 80 proof, and can be as high as 150 or 160 proof. An example of overproof rum is Bacardi rum. Overproof rum is usually used in mixed drinks, rather than served on its own.


Premium rum is in a special market category. Premium rums are generally from boutique brands, and are carefully aged and produced. As one would expect, they are more flavorful than “mixer” rums, and tend to be enjoyed straight.


Spiced rum is usually based on gold rum, and gets its flavors from the addition of spices such as cinnamon, rosemary, absinthe/aniseed, pepper, and very often, caramel.

results.description:
Wendy MacIsaac is a renowned fiddler from Cape Breton who has been playing music for over 30 years. She is recognized as one of the "old school" style of players who has kept the traditional sound going and has a deep respect for it.
Janine (Muise) Randall is a first generation American born of ex-pat, musical Cape Breton parents known for their legendary Boston house parties. She started step dancing as a young girl and later became a piano accompanist for Cape Breton dances and has performed with leading Cape Breton and Irish musicians from the Yukon to Scotland.
Here's a great opportunity to see/dance to these two great performers in the authentic Downeast atmosphere of the Canadian American Club. $15.00. Tickets available at BrownPaper for advance purchase or at the door the evening of the event. Cash Bar.
results.name: Wendy MacIsaac with Janine Randall- Traditional Cape Breton Music and Dance

results.description:
Fall into the Beatles!!(sorry about that one....ok not really!) Don't be a turkey....

It's the Beatles!! Well, ok the best local cover band!! The cover charge is $15. Come rock the night away. Cross posted with North Shore Social. 

From Johnny D's website: 
The number of Beatle Tribute bands is probably countless, but in New England, at least, none come more highly praised, critiqued or recommended as Beatle Juice. This band has taken on a history of its own. Their talent and showmanship go far beyond the norm in tribute bands. Sadly, with the recent passing of singer Brad Delp, their legacy draws even closer to that of the Fab Four's. Doing their best to fill Delp's Beatle Boots will be an array of local singers. Come Together for a special night of Mersey-side magic.

Tickets can be obtained via the link below:(note, they have a limited number of tickets available the night of the show at the door) 

http://johnnyds.tunestub.com/event.cfm?id=178044&cart

The meetup starts at 9:15.  I'll try to find space near the coat racks(the clock and washrooms are near that location at the end of bar) or to the area left of the ticket area. Not sure which will be open. *Also, I pushed the meet up time back because of "challenges" with finding a spot to meet before the concert. Also, when the music starts(usually seconds after 9:30), it can be difficult to find the group.

results.description:
We'll hike 9.4 mile starting at Appleton Farms thru Pingree Reservation, Bradley Palmer State Park and Willowdale State Forest!

This Hike Will require a car spot! We will meet at the end of hike and carpool to the beginning!

Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. I am committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up. 

Please note this is not a beginners’ hike. It is for intermediate level hikers and beginning hikers who keep in fit condition doing other things. You should be in good enough physical condition to keep up and stay with the group going at a moderate pace. Please do not show up for an event unexpected or unprepared.Bring water, hiking boots (not sneakers), bug spray and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy rain or extreme temperature cancels.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event. 

Please remember that I am a volunteer, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

 By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below:
Remember: I am a volunteer. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason

results.description:
Greater Boston Oasis and the Boston Coalition of Reason are thrilled to welcome Dr. Jason Heap as the Oasis guest speaker this Sunday! Jason has been a supporter of Boston's Oasis community since its very inception and we're so pleased he is able to join us. We're also delighted to have a return performance by guest musician Amanda McCarthy!

In the wake of recent events in American history where people have claimed that the religious liberty upon which America was based is being threatened, Jase will offer a brief insight into where the concept of "religious liberty" originated, including its historical context from England and how this shaped early Colonial life. Jase will be using some archival documents from the Bodleian Library of the University of Oxford and will demonstrate where some historical facts are stranger than the fiction often believed and reported today.

Doors for the event open at 10:00 AM for coffee and conversation, with the program starting at 10:30. We hope to see you there!

=========================================

Oasis meets in the Teen Center at the YMCA. To find the room, enter through the lower entrance (on Dartmouth Street, by the swimming pool), and follow Oasis signs from the front lobby to the Teen Center on the second floor. (Note: the stairwell to the Teen Center is NOT the stairwell in the front lobby. That is Stairwell A. The Teen Center is located at Stairwell B, next to the Yoga Studio. Oasis volunteers will be available to help provide assistance, and signage will be posted.

=========================================

Greater Boston Oasis is a secular community dedicated to providing for the human need for social and intellectual community, for those people who may not want or be able to have those needs met in a church or other faith-based community. 

Our Core Values are:

People are more important than beliefs


Reality is known through reason


Meaning comes from making a difference


Human hands solve human problems


Be accepting, and be accepted

Atheist or agnostic, freethinker or skeptic, deist or theist, all those with whom those values resonate are welcome to celebrate the human experience.
results.how_to_find_us: Follow signs from the entrance to the Teen Center room. Use the Dartmouth Street entrance, and head to Stairwell B. Teen Center is on the 2nd floor.
results.name: Sunday Gathering: Jason Heap - The Roots of American Religious Liberty

results.description:
This is one of the simplest forms of healing and self-development system that exists!

By opening and strengthening the energy channels of the body, it is possible to channel healing reiki energy to yourself and others – just by intention!

Kundalini means ‘coiled one’ and is known as latent female energy believed to lie coiled at the base of the spine.  In yogic theory, it is a primal energy, or shakti, located at the base of the spine. Different spiritual traditions teach methods of "awakening" kundalini for the purpose of reaching spiritual enlightenment. The Yoga Upanishads describe Kundalini as lying "coiled" at the base of the spine, represented as either a goddess or sleeping serpent waiting to be awakened. In modern commentaries, Kundalini has been called an unconscious, instinctive or libidinal force, or "mother energy or intelligence of complete maturation".

Kundalini awakening is said to result in deep meditation, enlightenment and bliss. This awakening involves the Kundalini physically moving up the central channel to reach within the Crown Chakra at the top of the head. Many systems focus on the awakening of Kundalini through meditation, pranayama breathing, and the practice of asana and chanting of mantras. In physical terms, one commonly reports the Kundalini experience to be a feeling of electric current running along the spine.

For our purposes we will be opening and awakening your energy centers and channels to gain access to and allow your kundalini to ‘rise’ up and out of your body cleaning and clearing out all that no longer serves your highest good.

During this workshop you will:

• Learn what Kundalini Reiki is

• History of Kundalini Reiki

• Learn about the 3 Levels of Attunements

• Learn how using Kundalini can benefit you and others

• Enjoy a guided meditative experience  & receive Level 1 Kundalini Reiki Attunement

Cost $40 - 2 hour workshop includes manual, level 1 attunement in person, then levels 2 & 3 via remote session, and a certificate (via mail) after your 3rd attunement is complete.

Your 2nd & 3rd attunements will be scheduled and be done via remote connection at a time convenient for you.  There will be at least 10 days between each attunement to allow for the integration of energy as needed.

Nicol is a Certified Usui, Lightarian and Kundalini Reiki Master.

No prior knowledge or attunements are required to receive and use this empowering energy!  Upon receiving your 3rd attunment, you will be a Kundalini Reiki Master and will be certified to attune others.

www.essencehealing.net
results.name: Kundalini Reiki Workshop and Level 1 Attunement

results.description:
These sessions at The Chinatown Community Center/Josia School will focus on a 6 week rotating schedule of classes designed to introduce the basics of Parkour in concentrate classes. The schedule will follow in order: 

• Safety, Landings and Balance

Class 1 will be focusing on how to land, move and stay safe practicing Parkour outdoor and in the real world. 

• Vaulting

Class 2 will focus on the foundation of Parkour - getting over low-level obstacles fast and efficiently through the use of vaulting.

• Precisions

Class 3 will focus on accuracy of jumping and foot/eye coordination honing basic standing and running jumps.

• Wall Techniques 

Class 4 will focus on conquering obstacles too large or tall to vault, in tandem with using walls as a means to keep a more efficient run.

• Tumbling/Acro

Class 5 focus is on tumbling and acrobatic skills, in pursuit of fully understanding movement in a 3D space and total proprioception.

• Flow + Speed

Class 6 links together all the previous lessons into one cohesive movement, and a timed obstacle course setting.

------

What if I've never done anything like Parkour before?  

This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun 

http://www.projectfreerun.com/
results.name: [Boston] Parkour 101 - Introduction to Parkour //

results.description:
BEGINNER TANGO: Absolute Beginning

Beginner Tango course is meant for people who either never ever danced Argentine Tango, took few classes long time ago or took few lessons quite recently but are not sure what they know or if they are ready for next level.

You will learn basics necessary to progress further. The material is presented in very organized manner allowing smooth progress from class to class. 

Please note that even if you dance other dances like salsa, swing, zouk or any of Ballroom or American Style dances, even if for years you took ballet, jazz, hip hop or any other of solo dances, you need to take the Beginner level class. The axis, the basis for the dance, musicality and partnership is completely different. Taking those 4 classes might be the life changing experience for you. It is obvious that having dance background helps, but it shall also give you enough experience to know that the basic classes are THE MOST IMPORTANT ONES, as they create a base for all your learning experience. What you don’t know will always and always chase you.

 It’s good to take this course to put all your information in order. You gain the necessary vocabulary and learn all the basic movements to be able to easily follow the explanations in higher level courses. Please respect our commitment to excellence. And make it your own.

No partner necessary. Join at any time – though we do recommend starting at the beginning of the cycle (see: http://www.ultimatetango.com/boston-classes.html for dates). You can take this course as many times as you find necessary for you.

The full course consists of 8 90-minutes classes plus exam/graduation even (about 4 hrs).


SIGN UP NOW: https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/ws?studioid=208847&stype=-7&sTG=25&sView=week
results.how_to_find_us: Follow your intuition and detective instincts. Still cannot find it? Email us at: ultimatetango@gmail.com

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

1:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

1:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

1:20 - Play!!!!!!

3:00 - Conclude the meetup with snacks and socializing


Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white t-shirt and a colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a dark or white "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, pinnies, sunscreen, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

results.description:
Happy Thanksgiving weekend everyone! This weekend we may have a visiting Urban Sketcher from Chicago. One of the founding members, Andrew Banks who is native from Boston. Andrew designed our current logo and made a watercolor of the Zakim Bridge to put on our upcoming USK Boston T Shirts.

Is not confirmed 100% but he'll try to make it to join us in this meetup!

Per members suggestion, this time we will be visiting the North End, home of the American Revolution, with its narrow streets and historical architecture (settled in about 1630's!) the oldest district in Boston.

Cafe Vittoria has very interesting interiors with the old coffee machines and their beautiful craftsmanship. We can enjoy great coffee and pastries or if the weather is nice we could visit Paul Revere's house or sketch the Old North Church

We can get together at the cafe and decide.

Here, a little history on the site:


"One If by land, Two if by sea"

The enduring fame of the Old North began on the evening of April 18, 1775, when the church sexton, Robert Newman, and Vestryman Capt. John Pulling, Jr. climbed the steeple and held high two lanterns as a signal from Paul Revere that the British were marching to Lexington and Concord by sea across the Charles River and not by land.  This fateful event ignited the American Revolution.

Founded in 1722, Christ Church in the City of Boston, known to all as the Old North Church, is Boston’s oldest surviving church building and most visited historical site.  In 1775, on the eve of Revolution, the majority of the congregation were loyal to the British King and many held official positions in the royal government, including the Royal Governor of Massachusetts, making Robert Newman’s loyalty to the Patriot cause even more extraordinary. The King gave the Old North’s its silver that was used at services and a bible.
results.how_to_find_us: 296 Hanover St Boston, MA 02113
results.name: Sketching the historical North End (and having great coffee!)

results.description:
Let's learn guitar in a fun group setting!

Players of all levels from beginner through intermediate+ are encouraged to attend. 

Any questions? Let me know at [masked].

Your host, Grey, is an international guitar teacher and founder of HubGuitar.com. Grey is a graduate of Berklee College of Music.

1. Please bring your own guitar. There are sometimes extras available to use but it's better to bring your own. You cannot learn guitar without your own guitar to practice at home! If you have questions about getting a guitar, ask at [masked].

2. Nothing else is needed. Just bring your guitar!

3. No experience is required. This is a beginner-level class. 

4. The class is one hour.

5. Please arrive ~5 minutes early. Late arrivals are disruptive and unfair to the learners who arrived on time, and so if you arrive late you may not be admitted to the class (depending on the teacher's discretion). 

6. This class is ideal for beginners. If you have more experience than this, you should consider booking a free trial private lesson instead: http://hubguitar.com/boston

Feel the burn with our sketching workout. Feel the flab flee from your fingertips. (OK, OK, you can go at your own pace.) But you just might need a break from all that food, family and ahem, discussions. Whatever the reason, I hope you will join us for a couple hours of sketching.

See you there.

The Prudential Building's Skywalk Observatory offers spectacular 360-degree views of Boston. We will arrive before sunset (which is at 4:13) to catch both daytime and twilight views. You will be responsible for purchasing your own ticket. Ticket prices are $17 for adults, and $14 for seniors (62 and above). Parking at the Prudential Center Parking Garage is $14 for 4 hours or $20 for 5 hours with a $10 minimum purchase from participating Prudential Center Shops. (After 5 hours regular daily rates apply, so customer beware!) The 116 Huntington Garage is across the street, and appears to offer a $12 flat rate. We recommend carpooling to save on gas and parking costs. 

Photos courtesy of Bill Damon.

results.description:
Join the Fresh Pond Walking Community for our regular Sunday walk around Fresh Pond.   

Let's join regular walkers from surrounding towns + members of five other walking groups and 20+ walkers for this walk.  Walk is on, Rain or Shine.

Few things are more enjoyable than a nice walk and a chat at the end of a busy weekend.

Since May 2012, we've met with a few other meetup groups Let's join for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

We walk clockwise, so if you get there late, just start walking counter-clockwise and you'll run into us.

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

Afterwards, we'll go out for dinner. We usually go for some unusual Chinese food, and the total cost is about $10 per person.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]
results.name: Weekly Multigroup Community Walk at Fresh Pond + dinner at Shangri La 11/29 3:30

group.name: Boston Late Risers Hiking/Walking/Biking Social Meetup

results.description:
Join The Oldest Established Permanent Floating Community Walk in Cambridge 

For the 200th consecutive Sunday, we will be walking.   Let's join 20 or so others from other walking groups for this walk.

The walk is on, rain or shine.


Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.


Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

We'll all go out for dinner afterwards, somewhere in the neighborhood.
results.name: Weekly Multigroup Community Walk at Fresh Pond + dinner at Shangri La 11/29 3:30

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE:  Panera Bread in Porter Square Shopping Center

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Panera Bread is right next to Dunkin Donuts. If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Sean and Arthur
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.
results.name: Gentle Yoga & Meditation - 90 minute class

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: Speeddating  Ages 35-45 -  SOLD OUT FOR MEN
